awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Population Neuroscience Approaches to Minority Discrimination and Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the relationship between perceiving/experiencing discrimination and mental and physical health outcomes. Research in diverse populations suggests that discrimination creates cumulative health effects over time.  Moreover, research on stress and stigma indicates that some populations are at particularly high risk for developing mental disorders, suicidality, self-harm, and substance dependence, especially those in 18-24 age range.  This project will advance scientists? understanding of how discriminatory social interactions impact mental and physical health at a critical time in the life course, with an emphasis on how social interactions produce neurological changes in our brains.
 
	The project employs social neuroscience design principles, combining survey methodology with experiments and neurophysiological measurements. Using Respondent Driven Sampling (RDS), a representative sample of college-age students will be recruited to participate in a survey that focuses on discrimination experiences, mental and physical health and behaviors, and social support networks. As a case in point, the sample will include individuals who identify as lesbian gay, or bisexual (LGB) and demographically matched heterosexual students. From this larger sample, a subsample will be drawn to participate in the second phase in which participants? brain responses to experimental tasks will be measured using electroencephalography (EEG) to capture neural event-related potentials (ERP) in response to target-locked stimuli that simulate ostracism. By focusing on health-related behaviors, self-reported mental health, and neurologically-based biomarkers known to correlate with mental and physical health outcomes, this study will advance scientists? understanding of the ways social interactions and constructs impact health through their impact on our brains.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation examines the relationship between perceiving/experiencing discrimination and mental and physical health outcomes among people living with a stigmatized identity. The literature on stress and stigma indicates that lesbian, gay, and bisexual (LGB) populations are particularly at risk for mental disorders, suicidality, self-harm, and increased substance dependence.  This project will advance scientists’ understanding of the ways social interactions and constructs impact health, with an emphasis on how such mechanisms influence our brains. This will be done via a research design with a tight focus on health-related behaviors, self-reported mental health, and neurophysiological biomarkers correlated with mental and physical health outcomes.

The overall research design was guided by population-based social neuroscience design principles that will jointly combine survey methodology with experimental design and neurophysiological measurement. LGB/non-heterosexual individuals were recruited from a Midwestern university and surrounding community using Respondent Driven Sampling methods. In addition, a matched sample of heterosexual participants was recruited through snowball methods to participate for comparison. Participants’ brain responses to experimental tasks were be measured using electroencephalography (EEG) to capture neural event-related potentials (ERP) in response to target-locked stimuli. Using an online survey with a valid sampling protocol for hidden and hard-to-reach populations in conjunction with ERPs, this project addresses two theoretically important and timely questions. First, how are discrimination and social support independently and jointly associated with self-reported mental health and health-related behaviors? The research employs social psychological frameworks, including the minority stress framework, to assess whether depressive symptomology and negative health behaviors in this population reflect exposure to discrimination.

Second, to what extent do prior experiences of discrimination predict differences in neural processing of social exclusion and rejection (such as differences in neurophysiological processing components and activation of brain regions in response to exclusionary stimuli), and do brain measures of the neural processing of social exclusion correlate with mental and physical health outcomes? Research shows that stereotype threat and perceived discrimination impact performance on experimental tasks and engage brain areas linked to emotional regulation as well as physical and social pain. We know little, however, about the ways in which brain function reflects stress related to identity-based discrimination, nor whether it mirrors equally important self-reported mental and physical health outcomes. This research proposes that neural activity can be measured and used as a biomarker for resilience against the negative effects of stigma and discrimination.

During the funding period, Elizabeth Straley and a team of 11 undergraduate research assistants collected survey and neural (i.e. electroencephalographic) data from 92 LGB/non-heterosexual and heterosexual participants aged 18 to 26 who had experienced varying levels of identity-related discrimination. While the neural data is still being analyzed, significant findings from the survey data can be reported. The experience of perceived discrimination based on sexual orientation does not directly affect mental and physical health and health behavior in non-heterosexual participants. Although discrimination is not a significant predictor of mental or physical health or health behaviors, there is a significant difference between the depressive symptoms and physical health of participants depending on their sexual orientation. LGB/non-heterosexual students report more depressive symptoms and worse health than their heterosexual peers. This research was shaped by the minority stress framework, yet those key predictors of negative outcomes were not significant for the participants in this study. For instance, experiences of prejudice, concealing one’s sexuality, and internalized homophobia do not predict physical and mental health outcomes in this study population. These findings contribute to a growing body of literature that posits that younger LGB/non-heterosexual individuals exist in a social sphere that has evolved since the theory was constructed and is less useful in understanding negative outcomes than it was in older cohorts.

The survey data will be incorporated into the analysis of neural activity in this dissertation which is to be completed in 2018. Taken together, the transdisciplinary dissertation contributes theoretically across a range of areas, including social psychology, health disparities research, and social neuroscience. In addition, by utilizing “population neuroscience” design principles, the proposed project also makes unique methodological contributions. Identification of brain biomarkers for addressing sociological questions is introduced for sociologists and population researchers, while novel sampling methodologies are demonstrated and incorporated into experimental designs for the social neurosciences.
